metadata.title: Sonochemical synthesis of two nano-sized nickel(II) coordination polymers derived from flexible bis(benzimidazole) and isophthalic acid ligands

Sonochemical synthesis of two nano-sized nickel(II) coordination polymers derived from flexible bis(benzimidazole) and isophthalic acid ligands
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.poly.2018.12.029 0277-5387/ 2018 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
⇑ Corresponding author. Fax: +86 0315 8805462. E-mail address: tsdgying@126.com (G.-Y. Dong).
Jun-Xuan Li, Dong Liu, Zhan-Bin Qin, Gui-Ying Dong ⇑ College of Chemical Engineering, Hebei Key Laboratory for Environment Photocatalytic and Electrocatalytic Materials, North China University of Science and Technology, No. 21 Bohai Road, Caofeidian new-city, Tangshan, Hebei 063210, PR China
a r t i c l e i n f o a b s t r a c t
Article history: Received 24 October 2018 Accepted 15 December 2018 Available online 24 December 2018
Keywords: Coordination polymer Crystal structure Nickel(II) Photocatalytic activity Sonochemical process
Two new Ni(II) coordination polymers (CPs), [Ni(L1)(IPA)]n (1) and [Ni(L2)(IPA) H2O]n (2) (L1 = 1,6-bis (benzimidazol-1-yl)hexane, L2 = 1,6-bis(5,6-dimethylbenzimidazol-1-yl)hexane, H2IPA = isophthalic acid) were synthesized by hydrothermal and sonochemical process. X-ray crystal structure analysis revealed that 1 possesses a 4-connected 3D architecture with a 65.8 CdSO4 topology, while 2 exhibits a 2D layer, which can be classified as a honeycomb 63-hcb network. The results indicate that Ni(II) mixed CPs structurally modulated by the flexible bis(benzimidazole)-involved co-ligands. The role of ultrasound irradiation power, reaction time and reaction temperature on the size and morphology of the nano-sized 1 and 2 were investigated in detail. Further, fluorescence and photocatalytic activities of nano-sized CPs for degradation of methylene blue (MB) are presented.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Treatment of dye wastewater is of great significance and result in strong reduction in their carcinogenicity and toxicity [1]. Photodegradation benefit from remarks like recyclability and eco-friendly feature was recommended for these waste water treatment [2]. Coordination polymers (CPs) with charming structures are of great current interest in the field of material chemistry due to their potential applications as functional materials, which could serve as efficient photocatalysts on the degradation of organic dyes [3–8]. Up to now, several strategies were used to explore the synthesis desired CPs and the relationships between their structures and specific properties. According to previously reported, the judicious selection of appropriate N-donor ligands is proved to be one of the most effective way to modify the versatile structures of mixed CPs [9–11]. Among a mass of N-donor ligands, long flexible bis(benzimidazole)-involved ligands, which can bend and rotate freely to satisfy the coordination preferences of metal ions [12,13].
The sonochemical approach possesses advantages of low cost, simplicity, short time, environment friendly and high yield of products [14]. Cavitation procedures including bubble formation, growth and quick collapse in liquid are caused by high-energy
ultrasonic irradiation, which results in local hot spots with temperature up to 500 C, pressure of 50 MPa with lifetimes of a few microseconds [15,16]. These extreme conditions can generate homogenous nucleation centers, further enhance the formation of nanostructured materials, and induce physical or chemical changes [17]. Masoomi et al. synthesized a serious of nanostructured CPs via sonochemical route, which can serve as precursors to prepare nano metal oxides [18]. Geranmayeh et al. reported successful preparation of a new nano Ce(III) coordination supramolecular compound via a sonochemical method, and the CP was used highly sensitive fluorescent sensor for copper ion [19]. Shahrnoy et al. reported the ultrasound-assisted preparation of a nanostructured zinc(II) amine pillar CP as a potential sorbent for 2,4- dichlorophenol adsorption from aqueous solution [20]. However, the application of nanostructured CPs as photocatalysts remains rarely explored.
To extend our previous research [21,22], we introduce the long flexible bis(benzimidazole) ligands including 1,6-bis(benzimidazol-1-yl)hexane (L1) and 1,6-bis(5,6-dimethylbenzimidazol-1-yl) hexane (L2) into Ni(II)/dicarboxylate system to explore the influence of N-donor ligands on the structures and properties of ternary CPs. Two Ni(II) CPs, [Ni(L1)(IPA)]n (1) and [Ni(L2)(IPA) H2O]n (2) (H2IPA = isophthalic acid), were obtained by hydrothermal and sonochemical approach. Besides, photophysical properties and photocatalytic activities of nano-sized 1 and 2 were investigated.

sections.heading: 2.1. General remarks
sections.text:
All reagents and solvents were commercially available except for L1 and L2, which were synthesized by a literature method [23]. C, H and N contents were determined using a Perkin–Elmer 240C Elemental Analyzer. X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) measurements were obtained on a PANalytical Empyrean diffractometer at 40 mA, 40 kV with Cu-target radiation (k = 1.5418 Å) over the 2h range of 5–50 . IR spectra were recorded from KBr pellets in the 4000–400 cm 1 range on an Avatar 360 (Nicolet) spectrophotometer. Themogravimetric (TG) analyses were carried out on a NETZSCH TG 209 thermal analyzer in flowing N2 at a heating rate of 10 C/min. A Hitachi F-7000 fluorescence spectrophotometer was used to measure the luminescence spectra for powdered solid samples at room temperature. The absorptivity value of methylene blue was recorded with a Puxi T9 UV–Vis spectrophotometer. The morphology of the photocatalysts was characterized by a JSM-IT100 scanning electron microscope after gold coating.
2.2. Synthesis of the single crystals [Ni(L1)(IPA)]n (1)
Ni(OAc)2 4H2O (0.1 mmol, 24.9 mg), H2IPA (0.1 mmol, 16.6 mg), L1 (0.1 mmol, 31.8 mg) and H2O (10 mL) were mixed into a pressure vessel. The mixture was heated at 140 C for 3 days, then cooled slowly to room temperature with a cooling rate of 5 C h 1, leading to the formation of green crystals of 1. Yield 35.2% based on Ni. Anal. Calc. for C28H24N4NiO4 (Mr = 539.22): C, 62.37; H, 4.49; N, 10.39. Found: C, 64.25; H, 4.33; N, 10.24%. IR (KBr, cm 1): 2924w, 2856w, 1638s, 1544s, 1526s, 1511w, 1401s, 1149s, 1080s, 990w, 863m, 530 s, 470w.
2.3. Synthesis of the single crystals [Ni(L2)(IPA) H2O]n (2)
The synthetic procedure of 2 was similar to the synthesis of 1, except that L2 (0.1 mmol, 37.4 mg) was used instead of L1. The green crystals of 2 (yield: 32.8% based on Ni) were obtained. Anal. Calc. for C32H36N4NiO5 (Mr = 615.36): C 62.46, H 5.90, N 9.10. Found: C, 63.55, H, 5.78, N, 9.34%. IR (KBr, cm 1): 3371s, 2937m, 2861w, 1604s, 1545s, 1515s, 1373s, 1158w, 1076w, 882w, 846w, 585w.
2.4. Synthesis of [Ni(L1)(IPA)]n nanostructures (1)
Ultrasonic syntheses of [Ni(L1)(IPA)]n nanoparticles were carried out in an ultrasonic bath at power of 240 W, temperature of 80 C and atmospheric pressure for 60 min with the same molar ratio, except that H2O (10 mL) was used instead of the mixture of H2O (10 mL) and EtOH (2 mL). The resulting powders were isolated by filtered, washing with distilled water and dried in air for characterization. 60.5% referred to Ni, Anal. Calc. for C28H24N4NiO4 (Mr = 539.22): C, 62.37; H, 4.49; N, 10.39. Found: C, 64.21; H, 4.29; N, 10.46%. IR (KBr, cm 1): 2922w, 2851w, 1643s, 1547s, 1525s, 1513w, 1400s, 1155s, 1085s, 992w, 866m, 526s, 464w.
2.5. Synthesis of [Ni(L2)(IPA) H2O]n nanostructures (2)
Nano-sized 2 was synthesized in a similar method to that of nano-sized 1 using L2 (0.1 mmol, 37.4 mg) instead of L1. The resulting powders were collected, 61.4% referred to Ni, Anal. Calc. for C32H36N4NiO5 (Mr = 615.36): C 62.46, H 5.90, N 9.10. Found: C, 63.50, H, 5.75, N, 9.28%. IR (KBr, cm 1): 3368s, 2935m, 2860w, 1601s, 1542s, 1518s, 1377s, 1163w, 1074w, 885w, 851w, 585w.

sections.heading: 2.6. Crystal structures determination of Ni(II) complexes
sections.text:
X-ray single-crystal diffraction data for CPs 1 and 2 were collected on a Bruker SMART 1000 CCD diffractometer at 296 K with Mo Ka radiation (k = 0.71073 Å) by the mode of x scan. The absorption corrections were applied with using the multi-scan program SADABS [24]. Structures were solved by direct methods and refined on F2 by a full-matrix least-squares technique using the
SHELXTL program package [25]. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The hydrogen atoms in water molecules were located from difference Fourier maps, while the other hydrogen atoms were placed in calculated positions and assigned fixed isotropic displacement parameters. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in Table S1 and the selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table S2.

sections.heading: 3.1. Crystal structure of [Ni(L1)(IPA)]n
sections.text:
The complex 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic system with the space group P21/n. As shown in Fig. 1a, the asymmetric unit of 1 is composed of one Ni(II) center, two half of L1 ligands and one IPA2 ligand. Ni(II) ion shows a NiO4N2 octahedral geometry with the coordination of four carboxylate oxygen atoms (O1, O2 O3A and O4A, symmetry code: A: x + 1/2, y + 3/2, z 1/2) and two nitrogen atoms (N1 and N3) (Ni1–O1 = 2.156(2) Å, Ni1–O2 = 2.078(2) Å, Ni1–O3A = 2.129(2) Å, Ni1–O4A = 2.084(2) Å, Ni1–N1 = 2.055(2) Å and Ni1–N3 = 2.058(3) Å). Moreover, the bond angles around the Ni(II) center fall in the normal range and are in good accordance with the values reported in the literature [26,27].
The IPA2 ligands adopt (j1-j1)-(j1-j1)-m2 mode of coordination and connect adjacent Ni(II) centers to form a 1D zigzag chain with the Ni Ni distance of 8.982(3) Å (as shown in Fig. S1a). Moreover, L1 ligand adopts the trans-conformation coordinated mode and acts as a l2-bridge, extending the neighboring Ni(II) atoms to form a 1D ‘‘X”-like chain (Fig. S1b). The two types of 1D infinite chains further interlink by sharing Ni(II) centers, leading to the formation of a 3D framework (Fig. 1b). In order to simplify the network of 1, Ni(II) centers can be defined as 4-connected nodes, IPA2 and L1 ligands as linkers. Thus, the 3D framework can be described as a 65.8 CdSO4 topological network (Fig. 1c).

sections.heading: 3.2. Crystal structure of [Ni(L2)(IPA) H2O]n
sections.text:
An asymmetric unit of 2 possesses one Ni(II) atom, one L2 ligand, one IPA2 ligand and one terminal H2O molecule. As displayed in Fig. 2a, the six-coordinate Ni1 atom displays a distorted octahedral NiO4N2 geometry filled by three O atoms from two IPA2 blocks (O1, O3C, O4C symmetry code: C: x, y + 1/2, z 1/2), one coordinated water molecule (O1W), and two N atoms from two L2 ligands (N1 and N4B, symmetry code: B: x + 1, y + 2, z + 1). The Ni–O and Ni–N bond lengths vary from 2.036(3) to 2.155(3) Å and from 2.052(3) to 2.077(3) Å, respectively.
In complex 2, the neighboring Ni(II) centers are linked by IPA2
ligands adopting (j1-j1)-(j1-j0)-m2 coordination mode to develop a 1D zigzag {Ni(IPA2 )}n chain (Fig. S2), in which the distance between two adjacent Ni(II) centers is 10.367(1) Å, the angle of Ni Ni Ni is 96.91(1) . Meanwhile, two L2 ligands link two Ni (II) centers adopting l2-bridge mode to form an approximately rhombus {Ni2(L)2}n metallamacrocycle. The 1D {Ni(IPA2 )}n chains via {Ni2(L)2} metallamacrocycle further extened into a 2D honeycomb 63-hcb network (Fig. 2b and c). Notably, the 1D infinite
{Ni(IPA2 )}n chains can extended into a 2D supramolecular layer by H-bond interactions (Fig. 2d), in which tetragonal plane networks are existed between two IPA2 ligands and two coordinated water molecules (O1W–H1WA O3D = 156.91(25) , O1W O3 = 2.745 (4) Å; symmetry code: D = x + 1, y + 1/2, z + 3/2).

sections.heading: 3.3. Effect of different N-donor ligands on the structures of the Ni(II) complexes based on IPA2
sections.text: From the structural descriptions above, the IPA2 ligands show (j1-j1)-(j1-j1)-m2 coordination mode in 1 and (j1-j1)-(j1-j0)-m2 coordination mode in 2, which connects Ni(II) ions and distinct N-donor ligands, thereby resulting in different structures. L1 and L2 ligand, as l2-bridge linkers, connect Ni(II) atoms with anti-conformation but distinct spacers, in which the distances between two adjacent Ni(II) centers are 13.162(4) and 15.214(4) Å for 1, 12.920 (1) Å for 2, respectively. Moreover, the dihedral angle of the two bis (benzimidazole) rings is 55.78(9) of entire L1 ligands in 1, and 0.00(12) of L2 ligands in 2, respectively. Thus, the Ni(II) atoms are connected by IPA2 ligands and different flexible bis(benzimidazole) ligands to generate a 3D CdSO4 framework for 1, a 2D uninodal 3-connected hcb layer for 2. The results indicate that no substituent group of the bis(benzimidazole) co-ligands could be favored to construct ternary high-dimension Ni(II) CPs.

sections.heading: 3.4. IR spectra, XRPD analyses and TG analysis
sections.text:
The IR spectra exhibit the main characteristic bands of L1, L2, water molecules and H2IPA ligands for nano-sized and bulk of
CPs 1 and 2. There are slight differences between nanostructured and bulk CPs, which may be assigned to the tablet is not uniform. 2 displays broad absorption band near 3400 cm 1, which correspond to the OAH stretching vibration modes of coordinated water molecule [28]. The absence of a band around 1700 cm 1 for ACOOH indicates that all of the carboxylate groups in compounds 1 and 2 are deprotonated [29]. The IR spectra of the H2IPA ligand show bands at 1691 and 1420 cm 1, while upon complexation with Ni(II) ions, the bands slightly shift their positions [30]. The strong peaks at 1638 and 1544 cm 1 for 1, and 1604, 1545 and 1373 cm 1 for 2 are indicative of the asymmetric and symmetric vibrations of IPA2 ligands. For N-donor ligands, the characteristic absorption at around 1494 cm 1 for L1 and 1503 cm 1 for L2 is attributed to the m(C@N) of the benzimidazole ring. While in the IR spectra of 1 and 2, the C@N stretching frequency shifted to 1511 cm 1 for 1 and 1515 cm 1 for 2, respectively, as a result of the interactions with the Ni(II) center [31].
To check the phase purity of bulk and nanostructured complexes 1 and 2, XRPD patterns were measured at room temperature. As shown in Fig. S3, the diffraction peaks of the simulated one from the single crystal data and experimental results match in the key positions, indicating the good phase purities of the compounds.
The TG curve (Fig. S4) indicates that 1 exhibits one step weight loss. The rapid weight decrease happened from 395 to 485 C, which corresponds to the decomposition of L1 and IPA2 ligands (calcd.:86.1%, obsd.: 86.4%). The residual weight of 13.6% is attributed to the generation of NiO (calcd.: 13.9%). Thermal decomposition of 2 possesses two stages. The first weight loss of 2.6% (calcd.
2.9%) occurred in the range of 60 to 105 C is attributed to the loss of one free water molecule. As the temperature is raised, 2 displays a gradual and obvious weight loss (calcd.:85.3%, obsd.: 85.5%) between 275 and 575 C, which can be ascribed to the decomposition of L2 and IPA2 ligands, accompanying the NiO residue of 11.9% (calcd. 11.8%). Nanostructured compounds are less stable than bulk of CPs and start to decompose at 350 C for nano-sized 1 and 40 C for nano-sized 2, respectively. A somehow lower stability of the nanostructures when compared with their single crystals, probably due to much higher surface to volume ratio of the nanosized particles [32].

sections.heading: 3.5. Morphological investigations
sections.text: To investigate the effect of ultrasound irradiation power, reaction time and temperature on size and morphology of the samples, the different ultrasonic power (120 and 240 W), distinct temperature (40 and 80 C) and times (30 min and 60 min) (Table 1) were carried out. The morphology and size of samples were investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM). As shown in Fig. 3, without ultrasonic irradiation, odd shaped particles were not well separated and exhibited larger particles up to several micrometers in size. As shown in Figs. 4 and 5, when the ultrasonic intensity increased from 120 to 240W, the size of sub-micron decreased from around 202 to 175 nm for complex 1, 238 to 176 nm for complex 2, respectively, which show that higher sonication power leads to separate uniformly plate-like (complex 1) or flower-like (complex 2) morphology and thickness particles [33]. Under the same ultrasonic power of 240W, more ultrasonic time (60 min) led to a decreased particle size (175 to 112 nm for complex 1, 176 to 135 nm for complex 2, respectively) but wider dispersion of particles, indicating that long time ultrasound irradiation decreased agglomeration, thus led to decrease particles size [34]. Further, samples were obtained under the same ultrasonic intensity of 240 W and ultrasonic time of 60 min, but different temperature (40 and 80 C), which shows well separated particles with average diameter of 88 nm for compound 1 and 93 nm for compound 2, respectively. Higher temperature results in an increased solubility, and thus a reduced supersaturation of growth species was present in the solution [35]. The experimental results above show that the size of nanoparticles decreased with higher ultrasonic power, increasing sonication time and higher temperature.

sections.heading: 3.6. Fluorescence spectra
sections.text:
The fluorescence properties of nanostructured complexes 1–2 and free N-donor ligands in the solid state are investigated at room-temperature. As shown in Fig. 6, the free N-donor ligands exhibit emission peaks centered at 340 nm (kex = 307 nm) for L1 and 354 nm (kex = 317 nm) for L2, respectively, which may arise
from the p*? p or p*? n transitions [36]. Nano-sized 1 exhibits red-shifted emission band at 354 nm (kex = 293 nm) compared with the free L1 ligand, which could be assigned to the combination of a the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy levels of L1 ligand coordinating to Ni(II) centers, a charge-transfer transition between L1 ligand and Ni(II) centers, and a joint contribution of the intraligand transitions or charge-transfer transitions between the coordinated ligands and metal centers [37]. For nano-sized 2, the emission peak of 327 nm (kex = 270 nm) exhibits a blue-shift with respect to the free L2 ligand, which is either ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) or metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) in nature [38,39].

sections.heading: 3.7. Solid-state diffuse-reflection study
sections.text:
The UV–Vis diffuse reflection spectra (DRS) of nanostructured 1–2 and the free N-donor ligands (L1 and L2) are shown in Fig. 7a. The absorption edges of L1 and L2 ligands are approximately about 335 and 415 nm, respectively, which may be ascribed to the p? p* electronic transition [40]. Meanwhile, the spectra of nanostructured 1 and 2 both contain the absorption components in the UV and visible regions. The nano-sized 1 and 2 exhibit broad
absorption bands in the range of 200–400 nm, revealing the complexes possess good UV-light response ability, which may be resulted from LMCT [41]. The weak bands in the visible region found at 648 nm for nano-sized 1, 640 nm for nano-sized 2, respectively, which should originate from the d-d spin-allowed transition of the Ni2+ (d8) centers [42]. As displayed in Fig. 7b, the band gaps (Eg) of nano-sized 1 and 2 can be determined by a Tauc’s plots of (F(R)hm)1/2 against the photon energy (hm), where R, h and m are the absolute reflectance, Plank’s constant and light frequency,
respectively. Thus, the estimated Eg is approximately 4.21 eV for nano-sized 1 and 4.10 eV for nano-sized 2, respectively.

sections.heading: 3.8. Photocatalytic activities
sections.text:
The photocatalytic activities of bulk- and nano-structured complexes 1 and 2 were evaluated using aqueous solution of methylene blue (MB) as a model pollutant under UV light irradiation (S1). Fig. 8 shows the changes in the C/C0 plot of the MB solution
against irradiation time (C is the concentration of the MB at time t and C0 is the initial concentration of the MB solution). In the blank experiment, there was no evident change for reaction times up to 150 min, reaching only 11.2 %. In comparison, under the same con-
ditions, the systems with different heterogeneous bulk- and nanosized 1–2 indicate an even improved MB degradation (85.6% for bulk of 1, 78.1% for bulk of 2, 90.6% for nano-sized 1 and 83.5% for nano-sized 2, respectively) (Figs. 9 and S5). Nanostructured complexes shows higher activities than that of bulk ones for decomposition of the MB dye in a photocatalytic process, possibly because the nano-sized complexes has the bigger specific surface area. The differences in photocatalytic efficiency between complexes 1 and 2might arise from the diversities in crystal structures.
Kinetic studies of photocatalytic experiments for the removal of MB were undertaken. The experimental data verified using kinetic models and best correlated was pseudo-first-order kinetic model, which is described by equation: ln(C0/C) = kt, where C0 and C stand for the concentration at initial and time t, and k (min 1) is the rate constant of the first order reaction. Fig. 10 exhibit reaction rates (k) of photocatalytic decoloration of MB, which are 0.0151 min 1 for nano-sized 1, 0.0103 min 1 for nano-sized 2, 0.0126 min 1 for bulk of 1 and 0.0091 min 1 for bulk of 2, respectively, which were distinctly higher than that of blank experiment (0.0007 min 1). Similarly, the k value of nano-sized 1 or 2 was also distinctly higher than that of bulk ones. These results demonstrate that nanostructured 1 and 2 could be expected to act as promising treatment for MB due to their high photocatalytic activities.
The reusability and stability are of the crucial issues to assess a photocatalyst’s performance. Fig. S6 shows that the photocatalytic ability of the samples only slightly decreased even after three cycles. Moreover, the photocatalytic process was carried out in aqueous solution under the UV light. After the photocatalytic trial, nanostructured complexes were separated and dried in air. As shown in Fig. S7, the measured XRPD patterns are in good agreement with corresponding simulated patterns. These experimental results confirm that nano-structured and bulk of 1–2 have excellent reusability and photostability in the process of photocatalytic decomposition of MB.

sections.heading: 3.9. Possible photocatalytic mechanism
sections.text:
To gain knowledge on the photocatalytic mechanism, the main oxidative species in the photocatalytic process was detected through radical and hole trapping experiments using tert-butyl alcohol (TBA, OH scavenger), benzoquinone (BQ, O2 scavenger) and ammonium oxalate (AO, h+ scavenger). It can be observed from Fig. S8 that the addition of AO did not affect the degradation efficiency of MB over nanostructured and bulk of complex 1 or 2, suggesting that h+ was not main reactive species in the photocatalytic
process. On the contrary, the photocatalytic decolorization of MB was obviously suppressed after the addition of TBA and BQ, illustrating that OH and O2 had certain contribution to MB photodegradation. On the basis of the experimental observations
and the existing literature [43], a possible photocatalytic mechanism in presence of photocatalyst (nano-sized and bulk of 1 or 2) was proposed for the above degradation reactions. The nanostructured and bulk of complex 1 or 2 upon irradiation of UV light generates electron–hole pairs and absorbs the necessary energy, electrons (e ) from the HOMO excited across its LUMO. The e in LUMO could be combined with dissolved oxygen on the surfaces of complex forming a O2 , which was transform into OH active species.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text: Two Ni(II) coordination polymers based on IPA2 and two flexible bis(benzimidazole) ligands were synthesized. Importantly, the substituent groups of N-donor co-ligands can play a crucial role in the structure of the result ternary Ni(II) CPs. The ultrasonic power of 240 W, sonication time of 60 min and the reaction temperature of 80 C may obtain optimal nano-particles, the size of nanoparticles can up to 88 nm for compound 1 and 93 nm for compound 2, respectively. Moreover, nanostructured 1 displays higher photocatalytic activity for the degradation of MB under UV irradiation than nano-sized 2.
